issue.title: [lit] convert verify test as lit FileCheck test part2
issue.body:
Convert second part of verify test shaders as lit FileCheck test.

This is for #5870

Still same files left in HLSL folder need to check.

comment.body:
> I just want to confirm that you did make the change to the three shaders I explicitly called out, but there are other shaders that are still incorrect. Please review each of the shaders in this PR that still have only one `RUN` line to ensure that they are correct.

Sorry. Missed the message :( Just noticed the diff.

Updated the rest.

issue.title: [lit] convert verify test as lit FileCheck test part1.5
issue.body: Add non-lib profile RUN line when possible.

comment.body:
> > There're some void main() without [numofthread]. Also one case with main but not have attribute on the parameter. None of these are valid entry functions.
> 
> Sounds to me like those are valid vertex shader entries.

Marked as vs.

pull_request.title: Add SV_BaseVertexLocation and SV_StartInstanceLocation to VSIn
pull_request.body:
New VS Input semantics SV_BaseVertexLocation and SV_StartInstanceLocation are added for
BaseVertexLocation and StartInstanceLocation of https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/d3d12/nf-d3d12-id3d12graphicscommandlist-drawindexedinstanced

Also added DXIL operation for these 2 input semantics.

Fixes https://github.com/microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/issues/2907


</details>

Can we merge these two diagnostics and use a select instead?

```suggestion
def err_hlsl_no_recursion : Error<
   "recursive functions are not allowed: %select{entry|export|patch constant}1 function calls recursive function '%0'">;
```

Then you can just add `0`, `1`, or `2` to select between “entry”, “export” or “patch constant” as appropriate.

pull_request.title: [Diagnostics] Improve recursion diagnostics, specifically for library shaders
pull_request.body:
Previously, there would be no recursion validation performed on any function declarations in library shaders. This PR adds code that validates that no function declarations that are found inside library shaders are recursive. The diagnostics aren't repeated, since there's logic to prevent the same diagnostic from being emitted by 2 similar ancestors of the same recursive function. The PR also adjusts recursion detection for shaders in non-library cases, and improves the original diagnostic by adding information about the name of the function that is recursive. The PR is meant to complete the work on issue #5789. However, more work needs to be done for full accuracy. 
The PR checks *all* function declarations in the translation unit for the library shader case, when it should really only be checking a subset of function declarations. This issue is filed here: #5857
Fixes #5789

repo.description: This repo hosts the source for the DirectX Shader Compiler which is based on LLVM/Clang.

comment.body:
nit: I have a strong aversion to introducing new code that uses Hungarian notation, and so does the LLVM style guide. This code is pretty mixed in how it names things, I don’t expect that you’ll fix that, but lets at least add new things with more style-consistent names.

https://llvm.org/docs/CodingStandards.html#name-types-functions-variables-and-enumerators-properly

comment.body:
If I’m reading this correctly we call this function only on library shaders, then we iterate all functions looking for the patch constant attribute.

Do we somewhere else verify that the patch constant attribute is only present on entry functions marked as hull shaders?

comment.body:
If this is only intended to stick around for debugging purposes, we should probably wrap the function in:

```c
#if !defined(NDEBUG) || defined(LLVM_ENABLE_DUMP)
```

So that we know it is for debugging only.

comment.body: I'm confused how spir-v tests are affected by this as this is workgraph specific code

pull_request.title: Remove ExtractRecordStructFromArray intrinsic
pull_request.body:
The ExtractRecordStructFromArray intrinsic is left over dead code that should be removed. This PR removes the intrinsic from existence. In the cases where this intrinsic was used, DefaultSubscript is used instead. 
Fixes #5351

   %2 = call %"struct.NodeOutput<loadStressRecord>" @"dx.hl.cast..%\22struct.NodeOutput<loadStressRecord>\22 (i32, %dx.types.NodeHandle)"(i32 9, %dx.types.NodeHandle %1)
   store %"struct.NodeOutput<loadStressRecord>" %2, %"struct.NodeOutput<loadStressRecord>"* %loadStressChild
   %3 = call %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle @"dx.hl.createnodeinputrecordhandle..%dx.types.NodeRecordHandle (i32, i32)"(i32 13, i32 0)
-  %4 = call %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle @"dx.hl.annotatenoderecordhandle..%dx.types.NodeRecordHandle (i32, %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle, %dx.types.NodeRecordInfo)"(i32 17, %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle %3, %dx.types.NodeRecordInfo { i32 97, i32 116 })
+  %4 = call %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle @"dx.hl.annotatenoderecordhandle..%dx.types.NodeRecordHandle (i32, %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle, %dx.types.NodeRecordInfo)"(i32 17, %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle %3, %dx.types.NodeRecordInfo { i32 97, i32 128 })
   %5 = call %"struct.DispatchNodeInputRecord<loadStressRecord>" @"dx.hl.cast..%\22struct.DispatchNodeInputRecord<loadStressRecord>\22 (i32, %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle)"(i32 11, %dx.types.NodeRecordHandle %4)
   store %"struct.DispatchNodeInputRecord<loadStressRecord>" %5, %"struct.DispatchNodeInputRecord<loadStressRecord>"* %inputData
-  %6 = alloca %"struct.GroupNodeOutputRecords<loadStressRecord>"
comment.body: Where is the HLSL for this? My expectation is that somehow this change made it so that it realized it didn't need two allocas for the same struct off the bat. This led to the elimination of the memcpy's which caught my attention. I worried that they might be related to what this test is trying to capture.

pull_request.title: Remove ExtractRecordStructFromArray intrinsic
pull_request.body:
The ExtractRecordStructFromArray intrinsic is left over dead code that should be removed. This PR removes the intrinsic from existence. In the cases where this intrinsic was used, DefaultSubscript is used instead. 
Fixes #5351

issue.title: ExecutionTest::HelperLaneTestWave failing with HLSL 2021 language version on AMD GPU

labels.name: external
labels.description: Issue beyond the scope of DXC

issue.body:
**Description**
`ExecutionTest::HelperLaneTestWave` is failing on AMD GPU after HLSL 2021 language version was enabled by default in commit https://github.com/microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/commit/634c2f349. Does not repro on any other GPUs. It does not seem to be related to the other `HelperLaneTest` issue #5667, at least the fix with adding `-opt-disable sink` does not help here. The test passes with previous language version (`-HV 2018` option).

**Steps to Reproduce**

`hcttest exec-filter *HelperLaneTestWave -verbose -adapter AMD*`

**Actual Behavior**

For shadel models 6.0 to 6.6:
```
Verifying IsHelperLane using Wave intrinsics in shader model 6.0
Using Adapter:AMD Radeon RX 6900 XT

...
Pixel shader with discarded pixel
...
FAILED: QuadReadAcross* - lane 0 / pixel (0,0) - IsHelperLane(), expected = 1, actual = 0
...
```
For shadel model 6.7:
```
Verifying IsHelperLane using Wave intrinsics in shader model 6.7
Using Adapter:AMD Radeon RX 6900 XT
...
Pixel shader with discarded pixel
...
FAILED: WaveActiveBitXor(IsHelperLane()), expected = 0, actual = 1
...
FAILED: QuadReadAcross* - lane 0 / pixel (0,0) - IsHelperLane(), expected = 1, actual = 0
...
FAILED: verify WaveMultiPrefixXor(IsHelperLane() ? 1 : 0, no_masked_bits), expected = 0, actual = 1
```

**Environment**
- DXC version https://github.com/microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/commit/634c2f3499832e0e9804635c9e21dcd262db3e4e or later (main branch from July 28 forward)
- Windows

labels.name: external

**Description**
`ExecutionTest::HelperLaneTestWave` is failing on AMD GPU after HLSL 2021 language version was enabled by default in commit https://github.com/microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/commit/634c2f349. Does not repro on any other GPUs. It does not seem to be related to the other `HelperLaneTest` issue #5667, at least the fix with adding `-opt-disable sink` does not help here. The test passes with previous language version (`-HV 2018` option).

**Steps to Reproduce**


- Windows

comment.body: AMD is investigating. Closing as external.

issue.title: Nuget Package does not integrate with VS 2022 ?

labels.name: build
labels.description: Issues related to build and setup

issue.body:
**Description**
I've added the nuget package to my VS 2022 C++ project and I can see it having added a new property page to the solution settings, but I cannot figure out how to compile my build-time HLSL code with shader model 6.6 - the dropdowns are not updated and if I add the corresponding command line switch manually in the property page it seems to be still calling the dxc from the sdk not from the nuget package.

I looked at what the nuget package provides and its targets file does provide VS integration and updates the search path, so I believe the VS integration of the nuget package is broken and does not work with VS 2022 ?

**Steps to Reproduce**
* create a C++ project with HLSL files using shader model 6.6 features
* add the nuget package to the project
* try to compile the HLSL files

**Actual Behavior**
* property pages do not offer entries for newer shader models
* wrong compiler exe is used and fails to compile the HLSL code

**Environment**
- DXC version: `dxcompiler.dll: 1.7 - 1.7.2308.7 (69e54e290); dxil.dll: 1.7(101.7.2308.12)`
- NuGet Package: `Microsoft.Direct3D.DXC` version `1.7.2308.12`
- Host Operating System: `win10 22H2 19045.3570`
- Visual Studio: 2022 preview 3 (17.8.0)

issue.title: Nuget Package does not integrate with VS 2022 ?

labels.name: build
labels.description: Issues related to build and setup

issue.body:
**Description**
I've added the nuget package to my VS 2022 C++ project and I can see it having added a new property page to the solution settings, but I cannot figure out how to compile my build-time HLSL code with shader model 6.6 - the dropdowns are not updated and if I add the corresponding command line switch manually in the property page it seems to be still calling the dxc from the sdk not from the nuget package.

I looked at what the nuget package provides and its targets file does provide VS integration and updates the search path, so I believe the VS integration of the nuget package is broken and does not work with VS 2022 ?

**Steps to Reproduce**
* create a C++ project with HLSL files using shader model 6.6 features
* add the nuget package to the project
* try to compile the HLSL files

**Actual Behavior**
* property pages do not offer entries for newer shader models
* wrong compiler exe is used and fails to compile the HLSL code

**Environment**
- DXC version: `dxcompiler.dll: 1.7 - 1.7.2308.7 (69e54e290); dxil.dll: 1.7(101.7.2308.12)`
- NuGet Package: `Microsoft.Direct3D.DXC` version `1.7.2308.12`
- Host Operating System: `win10 22H2 19045.3570`
- Visual Studio: 2022 preview 3 (17.8.0)

comment.body: I am glad to hear the issue is fixed. The VS is determining the drop-down values from the version of the dxcompiler.dll, and yes, most likely they are using the dll from Windows SDK to do so. The nuget package target/props file copies the dxcompiler.dll right next to the built binaries, so the compiler from nuget package is used in runtime.

issue.title: Node record should allow templated struct/class types

milestone.title: Shader Model 6.8
milestone.description: Shader Model 6.8 development tasks and bug fixes leading up to the retail release.

issue.body:
**Description**
It should be possible to use a suitable templated struct/class as a node input/output record type.
Currently any templated struct/class is errored as having zero size.

**Steps to Reproduce**
Simple example attached (as a .gz file as .hlsl is not accepted)
[node_record_template.hlsl.gz](https://github.com/microsoft/DirectXShaderCompiler/files/12618948/node_record_template.hlsl.gz)

**Actual Behavior**
The semantic check for a zero size record fails to handle templated types, and reports a zero sized record.
If that check is disabled, then asserts are hit during CodeGen, so bugs are present in both Sema and CodeGen.

**Environment**
- DXC version staging-sm-6.8 branch 
- Host Operating System any

issue.title: Make sure that objects cannot be inside the node record structs and add tests for it

milestone.title: Shader Model 6.8

issue.body: Make sure that objects cannot be inside the node record structs, such as a texture field inside the struct, and add tests for it.

pull_request.title: Remove unnecessary in C++11 c_str() calls (#5932)
pull_request.body:
While theoratically required in pre-C++11 to avoid re-allocation upon call, C++11 guarantees that c_str() returns a pointer to the internal array so pre-calling c_str() is no longer required.

llvm-svn: 242983

---------
